Introduction

In an era where resource depletion and rising raw material prices pose significant challenges, particularly for metal-dependent economies like South Korea, innovative solutions are crucial. The concept of a circular economy, which emphasizes resource efficiency and waste reduction, has emerged as a promising approach. This article explores a groundbreaking technology developed by Dr. Jae-Woo Choi and his team at the Water Resource Cycle Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST). They have devised a method to selectively recover high-purity gold from electrical and electronic waste using textile materials, offering a potential solution to the global e-waste problem.

The Challenges of Metal Recovery

Traditional adsorbents for metal recovery are typically granular, providing high specific surface areas for efficient adsorption. However, their underwater control is challenging, resulting in low recovery rates and potential environmental pollution. Fiber-like materials offer a more practical solution due to their ease of underwater manipulation and adaptability to various shapes through weaving processes. Nonetheless, their thinness and low strength make them susceptible to breakage during gold recovery applications.

post_title: Microsoft launches Phi-3 Mini, an AI model that is smaller but still rivals GPT-3.5
title: Microsoft Unveils Phi-3 Mini: Rivaling GPT-3.5 with 3.8B Parameters
post_content:
Title: The Power of Small: Microsoft's Phi-3 Mini Language Model

In the era of AI, where larger models are often seen as the key to better results, Microsoft is making a case for smaller, more efficient models. The tech giant has recently unveiled Phi-3 Mini, the first in a series of three compact AI models, with the other two being Phi-3 Small and Phi-3 Medium, set to launch in the coming months.

Microsoft has trained Phi-3 Mini on 3.8 billion parameters, making it the smallest model in the series. The next models, Phi-3 Small and Phi-3 Medium, will be trained on 7 billion and 14 billion parameters, respectively. To put these numbers into perspective, OpenAI's GPT-4 Turbo is reported to have been trained on over a trillion parameters, while Meta's Llama 3, set to launch in 2024, will have been trained on 700 billion parameters.

The number of parameters a model is trained on directly impacts its capability to deliver results. However, more parameters also mean higher power and energy consumption. While larger models may be ideal for complex queries or critical AI implementations, smaller models like Phi-3 Mini are more suitable for lower-powered devices such as smartphones. 

Microsoft has designed Phi-3 Mini to perform well, despite its smaller size. According to the company, Phi-3 Mini offers the same performance as models trained on more than 10 times the number of parameters. Although it may not match the capabilities of GPT-4 or GPT-4 Turbo, it is as capable as GPT-3.5. 

To achieve this performance, Microsoft trained Phi-3 Mini on a "curriculum" that included children's books. The company also used a larger model to generate AI-created children's books to supplement the real-world material. 

Microsoft is making Phi-3 Mini available for free on its Azure cloud platform, Hugging Face, and Ollama, an AI model service. By focusing on smaller, more efficient models, Microsoft is demonstrating that bigger isn't always better in the world of AI.

Target Now Stocks the Oura Ring: A Game Changer for Smart Ring Shopping

The Oura Ring, a popular smart ring known for its advanced health tracking capabilities, has made its way to Target stores. This partnership with Oura marks a significant step in expanding the wearable's retail presence, as announced on Tuesday.

In-store Sizing Experience

Purchasing the Oura Ring at a Target store offers a unique advantage: an in-store sizing experience. This feature eliminates the need to wait for a sizing kit by mail, confirm your size, and then receive the ring. However, if you're buying the ring online, you will still receive a $10 gift card upon purchasing an Oura sizing kit, which can be used for future Target or Target.com purchases, including the Oura Ring.

A Perfect Fit Matters

While smartwatches can be adjusted with wristband straps, smart rings require a precise finger fit. Historically, smart ring brands have mailed sizing kits before shipping the actual ring, extending the waiting period. Target's in-store sizing experience significantly reduces this wait time.

A Health Insight Powerhouse

The Oura Ring, despite being a niche product, holds immense potential. According to a DataHorizzon Research report, the smart ring market is projected to reach a $1 billion industry by 2032. Companies like Target and Oura are poised to lead this growth, transforming the Oura Ring from a novel wearable to an everyday product, easily accessible alongside your groceries.

A Growing Retail Presence

Target is the second retailer to offer the Oura Ring in-store, following Best Buy's international partnership with the brand in 2023. Amazon joined the trend in March 2024, selling the smart ring on its e-commerce platform.

In conclusion, the Oura Ring's availability at Target stores is a game-changer for smart ring shopping. With an in-store sizing experience and the convenience of an immediate purchase, the Oura Ring is now more accessible than ever.

Introduction

Health-monitoring apps have become an essential tool for many individuals, helping them manage chronic diseases or maintain fitness goals. These apps rely on machine-learning algorithms to analyze user data, but they can be slow and energy-inefficient due to the large models being transferred between a smartphone and a central server. To address this issue, engineers have developed machine-learning accelerators to enhance computation speed and efficiency. However, these accelerators are susceptible to attacks that can compromise user data. In response, researchers from MIT and the MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab have created a secure and efficient machine-learning accelerator to protect sensitive information while maintaining high performance.

Machine-Learning Accelerators: Speed and Security Trade-off

Machine-learning accelerators, such as digital in-memory compute (IMC) chips, help streamline computation by performing calculations inside a device's memory. IMC chips store pieces of a machine-learning model, reducing the amount of data that must be moved back and forth between the device and the server. However, IMC chips can be vulnerable to side-channel attacks, where hackers monitor power consumption to reverse-engineer data, and bus-probing attacks, which steal bits of the model and dataset by probing the communication between the accelerator and off-chip memory.

To tackle these vulnerabilities, the research team developed a three-pronged approach for their secure machine-learning accelerator: data splitting, lightweight ciphering, and key generation.

1. Data Splitting

To prevent side-channel attacks, the researchers introduced data splitting, a technique that breaks data into random pieces. When a bit is processed, it is divided into multiple pieces to ensure that no single operation can reveal the original information. To simplify the process of splitting data, the researchers optimized the computations required to generate the random bits, reducing the amount of computing needed.

To protect against bus-probing attacks, the team implemented a lightweight cipher that encrypts the model stored in off-chip memory. Title: Harnessing the Power of Nature: A New Era for Smart Windows

Smart windows, a groundbreaking technology capable of regulating light and heat, stand as a promising solution to enhance energy efficiency in buildings. However, their widespread adoption has been hindered by high costs and limited availability. A recent study by researchers at The University of Texas at Austin is set to revolutionize this landscape through the development of a new type of electrochromic device and materials, utilizing common and sustainable resources.

The study, published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, introduces a device that relies on eco-friendly, affordable materials derived from abundant biomass sources such as corn, potatoes, and beans. The key to this innovation lies in amylose, a natural polymer, which enables the achievement of excellent optical properties, sustainability, and easy preparation of electrochromic materials and devices.

"There's an urgent need to develop novel sustainable electrochromic materials and devices with excellent properties for smart windows," said Guihua Yu, a professor in the Cockrell School of Engineering's Walker Department of Mechanical Engineering and the Texas Materials Institute. "The biomass materials we extracted from corn, potatoes, and other common sources enable the achievement of excellent optical properties, affordability, sustainability, and easy preparation of electrochromic materials and devices. This potentially paves the way for the widespread use of smart windows."

Electrochromism refers to the ability to change colors in response to an electric current. In the case of smart windows, this color change allows for the filtering of light based on heating and cooling needs. By applying a low voltage, the researchers demonstrated the ability to decrease or increase the amount of light the device transmitted by more than 85% and modulate its transmission of ultraviolet, visible, and near-infrared spectra.

The technology proved resilient in experiments, withstanding over six weeks of ultraviolet exposure, 1,200 cycles of use, and 4,000 switches between light permeability. The simple, readily available materials, including a reusable, transparent electrode, contributed significantly to this discovery.

Title: Harnessing Artificial Intelligence to Detect Deception in High-Stakes Scenarios

A researcher from Virginia Commonwealth University has made a groundbreaking advancement in the field of deception detection. By training a computer to analyze data from a 2002 game show, this expert has taken a significant step towards determining the veracity of statements made in high-stakes situations.

According to Xunyu Chen, an assistant professor in the Department of Information Systems at VCU's School of Business, human behavior provides a wealth of cues for discerning trust and deception. Chen and his team have employed artificial intelligence methods, such as machine learning and deep learning, to capitalize on these behavioral cues for more effective decision-making.

In their study, "Trust and Deception with High Stakes: Evidence from the 'Friend or Foe' Dataset," published in Decision Support Systems, Chen and his colleagues utilize a unique dataset derived from the American game show "Friend or Foe?" This show is based on the prisoner's dilemma, a fundamental concept in game theory that investigates the challenges and benefits of cooperation and non-cooperation between two individuals.

Traditional lab experiments used to study trust and deception have limitations, such as reduced realism and generalizability. High-stakes deception, as observed in game shows, demands greater cognitive resources for behavioral management and often results in stronger emotional and behavioral fluctuations, such as facial expressions, verbal cues, and body language.

Chen's research has led to the identification of multimodal behavioral indicators of deception and trust in high-stakes decision-making scenarios. These indicators can be used to predict deception with high accuracy, paving the way for the development of an automated deception detection system.

The findings of this research have broad implications for various fields, including presidential debates, business negotiations, and court trials. By analyzing human behavior in high-stakes scenarios, practitioners can utilize this predictive model to identify deceit and protect self-interest.

This research marks a significant milestone in understanding deception and trust behaviors, which can result in substantial consequences. By harnessing the power of artificial intelligence, researchers and practitioners can now explore new avenues for predicting human behavior in various contexts.

title: AI Language-Driven: Framework for Human Motion in 3D Scenes
post_content:
Title: Enhancing Language-Guided Human Motion Generation with Scene Affordance: A New Era for AI-Driven Content Creation

In the ever-evolving world of artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning-based models that can generate various types of content have made significant strides. These advancements have opened new possibilities for filmmaking and robotics research, with AI showing potential in creating realistic or artistic images based on text descriptions. However, generating videos of moving human figures based on human instructions has remained a challenge. A promising new framework, presented at The IEEE/CVF Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition 2024, addresses this challenge.

Researchers from Beijing Institute of Technology, BIGAI, and Peking University have introduced an innovative two-stage framework that builds upon their previous work, HUMANIZE. This new framework effectively generates human motion in 3D scenes using natural language instructions while significantly improving the model's ability to generalize to unseen scenarios.

The proposed method consists of two main stages: Affordance Diffusion Model (ADM) and Affordance-to-Motion Diffusion Model (AMDM). The ADM predicts scene affordance maps from language descriptions, while the AMDM generates human motion from the description and pre-produced affordance map. By utilizing affordance maps derived from the distance field between human skeleton joints and scene surfaces, the model effectively links 3D scene grounding and conditional motion generation inherent in this task.

There are several advantages to this new framework compared to earlier approaches for language-guided human motion generation. The representations used by the model clearly define the region associated with a user's descriptions/prompts, enhancing its 3D grounding capabilities. This allows the model to create convincing motions with limited training data and provides a deep understanding of the geometric interplay between scenes and motions, aiding its generalization across diverse scene geometries.

The key contribution of this work lies in leveraging explicit scene affordance representation to facilitate language-guided human motion generation in 3D scenes. This study demonstrates the potential of conditional motion generation models that integrate scene affordances and representations. post_title: X is launching a TV app for videos 'soon'
title: X Unveils "Video First" TV App: Tailored Content, Free Speech Focus
post_content:
Title: X Unveils New TV App: A Revolutionary Shift to "Video First"

In a recent announcement, X, formerly known as Twitter, is set to launch a dedicated TV app, focusing on videos hosted on the social network. Spearheaded by X CEO Linda Yaccarino, this new app promises to deliver "real-time, engaging content" to users' smart TVs, aiming to create a high-quality, immersive entertainment experience on a larger screen.

The X TV app, sporting an interface similar to YouTube's, features a tailored trending video algorithm to keep users in the loop with popular content. Moreover, AI-powered topics will categorize videos by subject, providing a more organized and user-friendly experience. The app also supports cross-device viewing, allowing users to switch seamlessly between watching on their mobile devices and TVs.

X TV app is expected to be available on most smart TVs, though an official launch date has yet to be announced. Users can look forward to enhanced video search capabilities and an ad-free experience when the app becomes available "soon."

This announcement marks a strategic shift for X, transforming the social media site into a "video first" platform under Yaccarino's leadership. With original shows such as Tulsi Gabbard's and Jim Rome's, X seems committed to fostering free speech and offering a wide array of content.

Interestingly, X's TV app launch comes on the heels of Truth Social, a social media platform owned by Donald Trump's media company, which also revealed plans for a live TV streaming platform. Truth Social's platform emphasizes "news networks," "religious channels," and content that has been "canceled" or "suppressed on other platforms and services."

As X moves forward with its TV app launch, users can expect a more curated and interactive video experience on their smart TVs. By focusing on tailored content and free speech, X is poised to revolutionize the way users consume video content on its platform.
